text: On tap @ Fauners Tavern, NYC. This one has a slightly cloudy looking darker purple amber colored body. Low in the head department, only a small sidesticking pinkish red film. Smells really nice, sour and inviting. Lots of cherry stone, sour small cherries, strawberry and wild forest yogurt. A sourish tart berry infused really pleasant aroma. Tastes really nice also, but its not sour. At all. Feels nice and oily in the mouth and its just about average on the carbonation. Cherries, the sweeter kind, a little earthy strawberry water. Blueberries and grapes. Nice, lightdrinkable. 13.06.2017
330ml bottle. Pours cloudy burnt orange, thin, persistent off white head. Nose is fresh tart cherries, kirsch. Dusty cherry and cranberry flavors, medium length lightly sour finish.

Wonderfully balanced, fruit forward, a little long on the palate leaving the sour cherry lingering long after the glass, but as a porch-rocking option or meal starter, is an incredibly well-balanced beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Fruity semi-sweet, semi-tart cherry aromas that sweeten with a dark raisin note as it warms. Touch medicinal, but nicely balanced and a little touch of tart cherry when chilled. Lighter to medium body. Good for what it is.

Schönes rotes Bier schaum ist Ok, im Geruch frische aber auch Eingemachte Kirschen leichte würze, im Geschmack toll nach Kirschen frische Säure leicht malzig im Abgang ganz leicht Vanille und Karamell, ein tolles fruchtbier

11.2oz Flasche. Dunkelrot-braunes trübes Bier mit hellem Schaum. Fassgereifter Kirschduft. Dazu etwas Melasse. Antrunk frische saure Kirschen. Sehr tiefer Geschmack. Langes Kirschfinnish. Ist dass das Liefmans Kriek???

2015 Bottle. Ar: Cherry and hay, some raisins and maple syrup; a little bit of funk--of the barnyard variety. Ap: Murky brown; medium tan head with moderate-low retention, leaving a ring of finely bubbled foam and a patch of larger bubbles in the center. T: Sweet cherry and tobacco; some tannic wood notes, with more cherry in the middle; some treacle and dark caramel; very low bitterness, with no noticeable hop flavor; slightest bit of hay and barnyard on the finish. P: Medium-light body with very high carbonation, quite lush and mouth-filling; finish is medium-dry. O: A good example of a cherry ale; fair amount of complexity from the fruit, esters, and wood; nice level of sweetness and caramel flavors, too.
11.2 ounce bottle. Smells like wine. Tastes like a sour. Tart. Medium beige head. Reddish, brown in color. Looks yummy! Taste like cherry with a quick after bite. Interesting beer.
Pours a dark red-brown with a tall, light tan head. Sweet and sour nose. Tamarind fruitiness. The taste is much more tart than the nose would suggest. Nearly mouth-puckering. SweetTart candy flavor.
on tap at Craftys in Northeast Philly - nice dark red color. Good sour cherry flavor. Good stuff.

Very interesting. Not like any other kick Ive had before. Not sweet, not sour, just.... Different. Weird. Kinda like a tart cherry pie? Definitely wouldnt want a full bottle, but as a small pour, it grew on me. Wouldnt seek out again tho.

330ml bottle picked up at Total Wine in Reno 
Pours dark brown/ruby,with a medium sized beige head, some lacing. Aroma of dark cherries, leather and chocolate. Flavor of cherries, woody, toasted malts with a dry, tart finish 
Good, gets better as it warms up.

Second bottle, purchased as singles for the average unit price of $2.50. 11.2floz bottle, BBD "01 2021." Poured into a tulip glass. Appears dark plum red in color and a tan head. Smells like a cherry cough drop, but doesnt taste like one. Palate is mild to moderate tart, effervescent, and fairly light in body. A pleasantly dry cherry ale.

A very tasty sour! Hints of cherry, but not too sweet or sour. Pours a dark goldfish-brown with a medium head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Curious brew, with an aroma hinting at oak-aging and lactobacillus, yet nothing Ive read says theyre used during brewing, so I guess cherry ales just sorta taste like an oak-aged sour. Who knew. Pours a clear dark brown, offering up a slight off-white head with modest lacing. Taste is sweet but restrained, tart cherry meshing with the vinous dark fruit notes of a Belgian dark ale. Grows a bit soda-ish in the middle, sugary and indulgent, yet the tartness staves off the beer becoming cloy. Finishes semisweet and sour with a strong cherry fade.

Btl pours a clear light brown color with ruby highlights. Big fluffy tan head lingers leaving spots of lace on glass. Aromas of cherry pie,seltzer water, pie crust, cherry laffy taffy, wet hay and an earthy-musty wine cellar. Tastes of tart cherries,sweet taffy, mineral water and sour zots candy. Light body, watery mouthfeel, effervescent carbonation, and a dry tart-sour finish. The sweet malts along with the tart cherries mesh nicely with the mellow sour flavor making this ale highly drinkable and very refreshing. I really enjoyed this beer because it is not overly sweet like many Krieks. Very nice simple Belgian ale!
What is strange beer. somewhere between a Ludens black cherry cough drop and kool aid. Ever so slightly sour with very light brett notes. Sort of plastic cherry flavors. Light and poundable.

Confusing to buy as I associate Ommegang with mixed-style spicy brews, but on seeing that this is, in fact, a production of Liefmans in Oudenaarde, I figured it would be a fairly straightforward Belgian kriek, which it is. Great cherry aroma, nice fizz and body and very well balanced betwixt sweet and tart. This brew is not at all complex, just fruity, tasty and very enjoyable. I dont know a lot about krieks, but cant help wondering how this one compares to Liefmans other krieks.

Bottle from Varsity. Pours a slightly murky rusty brown with a finger of foam that lingers. Wood, musty basement, cherry aromas. Black raspberry, cherry, cobwebs, wood on the palate. Smooth, lingering cherry. Nice!
Draft at Nosh. Sweet, but not cloyingly so. Quite refreshing with a fairly clean finish.

Bottle. Pours cloudy reddish amber. Aroma is cherry, stones, red fruit, light funk. Body is light, tart, sour and fizzy. Still nice cherries, yet turning rather artificial. Palate is spritzy and fruity, but also dry and rather short. Quite good.
Cherry beers can run uber-sweet or uber-tart but this one strikes a delicate balance. Taste is a little one-dimensional but whats wrong with just popping a few cherries?

Red in color with a good clarity & off white head. Nose is cherry & cider with a subtle trace of lactic acid. The flavor is reminiscent of a cherry soda & cider: big cherry flavor on a light, effervescent body with notes of lactic sourness the is subtle, but notable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Huge aroma of cherries mostly, plus caramel, a touch of vinegar, yogurt. Dark brown, cloudy, with a thick head. Lightly tart flavor, great fruit, malts, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, yogurt. I would prefer it to be a bit more tart, but this is lovely, huge cherries. Full and soft, somewhat light, and nicely spicy.

11.2 oz. bottle, consumed on 1-25-17. Purchased 12-31-15, so it has aged for over a year. Pours an elegant, dark amber with a moderate amount of beige to taupe head. Pleasant, tart cherry aroma. Mineral smell. Nice, tart flavor. Subtle cherry and cherry cordial. Cherry cola. Nice mix of spices (I dont think the beer actually is spiced). This tastes better than I remember from other bottles in the four-pack that I consumed without significant aging. Light to medium body. Lively in the palate; good bite. If the body were a little bit fuller, the palate would earn a 4. A really enjoyable beer; I do recommend aging. Good stuff!
Dark amber brown. Massive cherry pie malty nose but not sweet or cloying. The mouth is perfectly balanced between malt and mild sourness of the cherries. The cherries linger a bit in the finish.
330 ml - So glad to find a New York brewed sour. Red color, brief white lace, many twists and turns.

Appearance is a brownish color with a red hue. The aroma contains cherries, oak, and caramel. The flavor is faintly sour with some cherries going on. There is also some caramel and toffee flavors adding to a slightly malty flavor. Overall this might be like a Flanders Light but it is still very good.
Pours an amber brown with an artificial cherry aroma. Taste is tart cherry, with a light oak flavor. An easy drinking beer, not too fruity, with a quickly dissipating aftertaste.
Dark brown pour with slight off-white head. Aroma of tart cherry barnyard funk, and some wood. Tart cherry flavor with oak, and musty funk. Very nice.
Shared 33cl bottle. Pours amber-brown with an off-white head. Aroma is vinous, cherries, funk, tart. Taste follows nose with some vinegar. Sweet finish.

Aroma: tons of cherries; Appearance: very dark red/amber with thin white head that lingers; Taste: sweet and fruity with faintly underlying funkiness; Palate: medium body with long, sweet finish; Overall: fairly one dimensional but pleasant. Might get again.

33cl bottle pours dark crimson with a lacy off-white head. Aroma is big cherry, quite a potent potable, not too medicinal. Flavor is medium sweet, very fruity. No real hop note to think of. Medium bodied, nicely carbonated. Good for a fruit beer.

Bottled. The aroma is fruity, tart with cherries, lime, grapefruit and oak. Very complex. The body is dark brown, with a small white head. The taste is oaky, with lovely tart cherry notes and a nice tart finish with citrus.
Brown pour with hints of red. Get some cherries in the nose but not a great aroma. Taste is tart sweet cherries. Very nive fruit ale.
Dark reddish brown pour with a thick beige head. Nice cherry aroma. Good cherry flavor with a little bit of funk.

Draft at mudville9. Pours a dark brown purple color with light head . Taste is sweet and fruity with cherries. Good fruit beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2016 On tap at brewery. Pours a reddish brown with a small foamy off-white head. Aroma is cherries with a little bit of funk. Taste is sour cherries with a little bit of vinegar, grassy hops, some malt, oak, and a hint of yeast. Dry-ish finish. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Sticky mouthfeel.
Bottle: Dark brown with a small ring head. Pitted fruit aroma with malts. Sweet cherry flavor followed by a great tart aftertaste. Absolutely delicious.
If you like sours and cherries... this one is for you. Dark fruit notes linger with the tartness. Quite well done. You get some woodiness in the background, perhaps a musty dark paneled room.

Tap - small foamy head, deep red Amber color, definite cherry aroma and flavor, moldy sweet but also balanced with a touch of tartness, good overall for a cherry beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours slightly reddish brown with lasting skim and ring of beige foam. Lots of cherry on the nose as expected with a good bit of musty funk. Flavor follows almost identically with the added twist of a tart bite mid-sip. Finish is somewhat dry with lingering cherry. This is good stuff, but could be sweeter.

Deep dark brown muddied body with a slightly violet or ruby glow and a small, single centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of pure cherries, sour funk, grass, earthy malt and a bit of yeast, bread and alcohol - fairly light though. Medium-bodied; Very nice and structured cherry flavour at first with a slightly sour, but mostly sweet flavour, a good deal of supportive malt that shows very well and balanced with the sour and sweet flavours of the cherries, with a hint of alcohol at the finish. Aftertaste shows the sour notes up front, but end with a great smooth cherry flavour and a nice complexity from the yeast. Overall, this is all about the cherries of course, but the balance and malt here are great - they support the beer, but the cherry flavour is still front and centre. A great beer that everyone should have if they can find it! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Whole Foods in New York (Bowery), New York on 28-May-2016 for US$3,99 sampled at home in Washington a few minutes after completing the USMC Marathon 2016 on 30-October-2016 with my wife, congrats Amanda!
A delicious cherry beer. Deep plum color. Holds a good head throughout which is rare for the style.

Drunk from a tulip, pours a lovely deep red, slight frothy head, the initial nose is fruity and a bit sour. Taste is cherries, deep sweet cherries though not at all tart, at least at first. Very well balanced brew. Would drink again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle picked up in Hilton Head for my wife then I realized I hadnt rated this. Pours a clear dark reddish mahogany color with a small off white head. The aroma has plenty of nice cherry character, sweet, some tart, as close as any beer to NG Belgian Red but that is where the comparison stops. The flavor has some nice cherry character, lightly tart, but fades to the finish, a splash of chocolate, caramel, pale malts, good.

Ive seen decent comments on this "beer". Let me say right away that I wasnt warned about this brew. There I am, looking for a dark beer at our local Oktoberfest. So, I see them pouring this and I say "I want one of those nice dark beers". No warning. The chick never said "this isnt your typical dark beer". She never mentioned it was a sour. So, I get my beer, and walk away a happy man, thinking I am about to sip a nice stout, but instead, I was greeted with a taste I can only describe as equivalent to a sour Warhead shoved up Rosie ODonnells ass and then crafted into a beer for some unsuspecting fellow just looking for a dark stout. Yep. This beer SUCKED. Now, to be fair, there are many who like "sours". Had I been told it was a sour (which I should have been), I never would have tried it. But, since I was subjected to something that tasted worse than my ex-wife, I wanted to write a review.

Very nice aroma and color, has a nice taste where you can taste the cherries I found it very pleasing to the palate, It isnt my favorite Ommegang offering, but would gladly accept another bottle anytime.

12oz bottle (Filo Liquors, Abilene, TX). Pours a very dark maroonish brown (but hold it up to a light  suddenly it is an unbelievable translucent red with gold tint!) with a light white head that fades fairly quickly to a small "island"; a few millimeters of sticky lacing stay on the glass. Aroma highlights tart cherries, sourness and light wood, with some sweet malty notes. Taste features the same tart cherry flavor up front, giving way to some grape must and wood characteristics. Medium dry finish with a very light texture and extremely effervescent, almost champagne-like in its level of carbonation. I have been looking for this beer for nearly a year  and boy am I glad I finally found it!

Taps translucent reddish chocolate brown with a fair pale buff head. Tart Cherry dominates the aroma but shares the stage with subtle malt and woody notes. Cherry is still the headliner in the flavor, which presents wine-like character. Cherry wine? Warum nicht? Mouthfeel offers average body but good fizz. Three cheers for cherries!

Very sweet start but tart finish. Not my favorite style but the cherry flavor is good. Nice tart finish. Deep red color. Small head. Nice carbonation. Well done. Interesting to see an Ommegang offering that was brewed at the parent in Belgium.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2016 Bottle. Moderate grain for the malt, light grass for the hops, heavy musty and damp basement for the yeast, with vinegar and cherries in the background. Head is average to large, fizzy/frothy, light beige, with good slippery lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is dark red/brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately to heavily acidic, then finishes moderately acidic and slightly bitter. Palate is medium, slick with a lively tiny bubble carbonation, and a tart finish. Excellent Fruit Beer, but seems more like a Sour with cherries to me.
Bottle. Aromatic of cherries and malt. Rich ruddy brown with a cafe head. Cherries dominate with some oak and vanilla. Pretty sweet but in a tasty way. Wish I had another one!

11.2oz bottle 9/15/16 (Cost Plus World Market Singles Rack)-42° in shaker-Pours a dark amber with a small tight off white head. Aroma of cherries and Belgian. Taste of tartness, cherry, and slight chocolate. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and quite easy to drink. Great brew.

Pub W, Norman, OK, draft. Equal parts cherries, Coke and vanilla. Is it beer? I don't know. Is it delicious? It is pretty delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Crunchy's. Pours brownish red. Very tart aroma. Thick with lots of cherry. Okay but a bit too sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Quite excellent, reminiscent of Kasteel Rouge (which I like very much) but with better balance and more fresh cherry than syrup. Red-brown, excellent malt from what seems like a belgian brown base beer and then well-balanced cherry tartness. Yum.
Not bad. Has a really intense cherry flavor. Pretty easy to drink. Could tolerate in small doses.

12 ounce bottle

A just below world class fruit beer shines from start to finish. It bears some resemblance to the soda like cherry lambics but somehow adds more. Id love to try it on draft at some point to see if it tastes brighter or more vibrant.

Aroma / Appearance - A deep fluid black base seeps downwards with one mission - to sweet the pint glass. Sweet cherries, malt, and fruit bloom. If not for a couple of slight variances this would be a dead ringer for New Glarus Apple Ale.

Flavor / Palate - Cherries dipped in bittersweet Hershey kisses warm the palate. The fruity body then marches to a strong focused finish of pure malt. A little more clarity would not hurt but this generally gets the job done. Id certainly spring for a few more if the fridge were empty.
(Draught) Pours a cloudy deep amber-brown body with a medium beige head. Aroma of cherry, band-aid, almond, light chocolate, and brown sugar. Flavor of cherry, light wood, and caramel.
strong tart cherry aroma. dark red in color with decent head. strong cherry flavor with smooth finish.
bottle - Pours a deep ruby color and smells mainly of tart cherries. It has a sweet, assertive cherry and malt flavor with enough tartness to balance it nicely. Medium bodied. Lively. Very good.
reddish-brown color; nice tart cherry aroma with oak notes; nice cherry flavor; just slightly tart with mild oak notes; nice and smooth
hits the mark. on tap at the abbey in boston. dark colour with some lace. fairly smooth.good though not the most representative kriek as a bit cherry coke.

appearance: dark brown-garnet, with a scattering of creamy light tan froth around the rim.  aroma: muddled cherries, raspberries, hint of molasses, leather, and earth, with a dose of pipe tobacco.  taste: sweet, tart, and sour, with cherry, root beer, marzipan, raspberry, some balsamic vinegar. finish: 	dry, with notes of almond, oak, and some brett funk. notes: Really well done. Felt like a sour red, not a fruit beer, but thats quibbling. Great palate, very drinkable. Draught at World of Beer in Rockville, Maryland.

Draught at Golden Gate Tap Room. Dark ruby color, pink head. Sour taste with cherries, tart, wheat, cookie dough and grass. Sour finish with cherries, tart, wheat, earthy notes and grass. Very nice sour.

Pours hazy reddish brown with fairly tall off-white head. Aroma of cherries, almond icing, bretta, red berries; its got the Liefmans signature all over it. Taste is sweet, fruity, candy like and slightly artificial with a very dry finish. Light, crisp body with average to lively carbonation. Cant help feel this would have a lower average if it flew under the Liefmans brand.
Dark reddish brown with a light tan head. Tastes like cherry candy. Strong cherry aroma, pleasingly tart with just enough sweetness. Dry, earthy finish.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle at Quarry House Tavern in Silver Spring, MD. 

Deep ruby-brown with a small beige head and good lacing. 

Aroma of dark berries and tart cherries. 

Taste of tart cherries, malt dark berries and oak. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation with a nice mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma was strong fermented cherries and malts. Taste is similar dark cherries, sticky malts, and light alcohol burn.

On tap at Republic Seven Corners. Pours a deep purple with a ruby hue and tan head and red hue that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of sweet cherry with a light tartness and sweet grain underlying. Flavor has sweet cherry up front with a slightly tart finish and some sweet grains backing.
Draft. Pours a reddish brown color. Aroma and taste are tart cherries and some sweetness.

33cl bottle. Medium beige head atop clear dark red-brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, cherry, wood, Brett. Taste is moderately sweet, cherry, some sourness, light wood. Soft light-medium body, light stickiness, effervescence.

330ml bottle. Pours a clear red-copper with a medium, long lasting, beige head that laces nicely. Sweet aroma of tart cherries and Brett. Sweet flavour of cherries, yeast, oak and Brett with a dry, tart, acidic finish. Light body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. A good fruit beer.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip: Pours brown with a decent khaki head. Aroma of cherries, wood, other dark fruit, sugar. Taste is more of the same, pretty sweet, mildly tart, lots of cherry and oak. Pretty good beer, a little too sweet.

New Beer Distributors, NYC bottle: pours brownish with a beige head. Aroma is cherry, wood, yeast, vinegar and sugar. Taste is a bit tart. A little sweet. Nice aftertaste. Tastes very Belgian. Pretty nice.

On tap at the brewery. Nice woody-cherry fruit aroma, some tart-sweet fruity-acetic-balsmic quality. Dark ruby amber clear with thin head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts moderately sweet with nice cherry tart notes. A little woody. Nice tart-sweet-acetic character. Finish is fruity and tart, with lingering cherry after.

Draft. Ruby red color. Taste is cherries. Light sour. Fruits. Medium light sweetness. Average carbonation. Pretty refreshing. Cherry aging really comes through. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Mahogany body with light tan head. Tart berry, herbal, spicy caramel aromas. Tart cherry, herbal, spicy caramel flavors----good fruit brew.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
11.2 oz. bottle with a BB date of March 2021 on the label. 

Look: crystal clear, dark copper body with a durable light tan head that coats the sides of the glass as it subsides

Aroma: woody and fruity, with dark and sour cherries; hints of yeast.

Taste: More fruity and less woody with a touch of earthy yeast. Nice mix of bitter, sweet and tart, with the balance of these changing from start to finish. 

Feel: medium body with near medium carbonation. 

Overall: recommended.
Pours a reddish amber color with a beady canvas colored head. Notes of wood, faint sour cherries, and malt. Slightly tart mouthfeel.
Draft at Hales Ales in Hilliard: reddish-brown pour, off-white head. aroma of fruity cherry, wood. tastes are cherry cola vibe, faint tart, little candied, oak.
Bottle shared by PinkZambia clear medium brown malty Woody dark cherry flavors. Malty and a little bitterness at the end. Smooth

Heavy mashed ripe sour cherries in scent. Medium pinkish brown in color. Nice carbonation. Vinegar sours up front, the fruit is more of a stale back of the mouth feel and taste. Not sugary, but not a sour. An even level for a fruit beer thats not too "girly", sorry ladies. Tap

Heres a fruit beer that doesnt pound your palate with candy fruit sweetness. Brown and a hint of rose. Alex quality balanced with some sour fruit but it isnt intensely so. Decent but not incredible. Bottle.

Bottle. Brown color in the glass. Aroma has yeast and cherry. Balanced flavor, lots of cherry and wild yeast that brings it up to the edge of being sour, but it doesnt quite get there. Good fruit flavor, and the yeast makes it interesting.
Bottle share. Brown amber in color with a small tan head. Sweet aroma of cherries, carries through to the taste. Mostly sweet cherry fruit in the taste, but a little tart too.

11.2oz bottle thanks Toby. Pours out a clear brownish hue, surprising as I was expecting some a bit more red. Small beige head. Typical kriek aromas, more candy sweet than natural fruit. Taste follows the same pattern. About the norm, middle of the range for the style.

On draft. Good tart cherry fruit beer from a brewery that knows how to make traditional Belgian beer. Plus, it was available on tap at a local sports bar -- if that isnt progress, I dont know what is.
Pours dark with a nice beige head, aroma of yeast, malt with candy, toffee, dark fruits, flavor of Cherries, acidity, dark fruits, slightly stale, medium bodied

This has a nice enough natural tasting cherry flavor to it but its not really doing it for me overall. Its brown with a big, thick head. The cherry is up front in the nose w/ some malty undertones and it is similarly predominant once tasted. There is a hint of tartness, presumably from the fruity, which I feel kind of clashes w/ its rather thick texture. This seems like it had a lot of carbonation in the bottle but ended up a bit lifeless in the glass as well. Overall, I do like how the cherry is incorporated here but its really only an above average beer.
11.2oz bottle thanks Toby. Pours out a cola color topped with a sand head. Nose is nice candy cherries some malty notes. Taste is more of the candy sweet cherries and a nice notes.

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $ ? ][ schnapps snifter ][ 01.09.15 ]hazy cherry-almond, thin white ring, wispy top. Very sweet, red berry flesh, full bodied and fizzy, thin watery experience with lightly synthetic plastic.
The aroma has notes of cherry, plus grassy hops and malt. The taste is quite balanced; sour, yes, but not too much. The palate is both invigorating and substantial. An excellent beer.

At SAVOR 2016. Poured an amber color with a small foamy head. Aroma was tart cherry skins, light swet malt. Very mild herbal hop notes, but mostly a cherry, funky character to it with a touch of sour on the finish.

3 oz. from bottle; from Old Town. Aroma: Cherry that is moderately sweet and lightly tart; a touch of chocolate. Appearance: Oud bruin-like appearance with a solid tan head that settles into a patchy skin. Flavor: Cherry is most tart up front (still not intensely so) with some balancing chocolate; cherry sweetness shows up thereafter, and lingers on through the finish. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, very soft carbonation, lingering finish. Overall: Not going to be mistaken for Goudenband anytime soon.

Pours a dark murky brown with minimal off-white head. Aroma is tart wild cherries. Flavor is sweet and sour with enough backbone support the guilty cherry pleasure.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Bru Craft. Very dark copper pour with a slim top of tan foam. A few spots of lace. Semi-glossy black cherries with a dry tannic finish. Notes of other dark red fruit (currants, pomegranate, plums, raspberries) but mostly just cherry. Hints of dark chocolate. Has a slight spicy hop bite and tons of wood tannins to balance out the sugars. A few acetic notes. In balance works quite well.
Not in any way complicated this pours amber red with a short lasting beige head. Not too carbonated, the taste is sour cherries and not much else. Perfect though for a hot summer day.
Bottle. Pours an amber with a tan head and tart cherry aroma. Taste is tart as well, with cherry coming through along with wood, brett, sour and tart cherry notes into the finish

With Z, pours an amber cherry red with an ephemeral beige head. Nose is through and through cherries, fruity and not running over with any hard thick sweetness. Taste is pleasant tart cherry, with  wood  and a very subdued buried sweetness. Finishes on the pleasant tart cherry wood notes . Nice . quaff score 8 / 10
Perfect thirst quencher. Cherry, lactose, and of course quite a bit of sourness going on. Very well balanced. Serving: 12oz snifter, Luce-- rated with beerbasher app for shitphone
Bottle: pours dark reddish brown with a foamy, pinkish head, aroma of tart cherries, taste is slightly sweet, tart, lots of carbonation with a dry finish
Bottle. Dark brown beer with a tan head. Cherry and rich malt aroma. Cherry and rich malt flavor. Medium bodied. Cherry and light dark malts linger.

Bottle into a tulip. Pours dark red, with a small tan head. Nose is sour cherries and spice. taste is pleasantly tart, with big cherry flavor mixed with raisins and dark fruit. Finish is medium length, with a nice sour cherry aftertaste. Outstanding.

Sampled in a large tulip glass, poured from a bottle, 
this ale was a dark red in the glass with some darker red and brown hue at the edge of the glass, and the pour gave a one finger or so off-white, light tan cover, 

the nose had cherry fruit, sour and tart fruit notes with a little rhubarb and sour grape, a little grain and there was some cherry sweetness, 

the flavors were cherry, light malt, sour and tart fruit that resembled grape and other fruit, a little grain, and some cherry sweetness, 
the finish had a light to less than medium sour-tart fruit bitterness, 

the mouth feel was light to less than medium, it was a little creamy and had some sour-tartness that gave some dryness to the mouth, the carbonation was soft to average, 

a beer with cherry fruit nose and flavor.

Bottle. Pours a dark red with brown highlights and a high, fine-grained, off-pink lacy head. Nose is dark cherries, lactic sourness, acetic acid, vanilla, powdered sugar, and lemon. Crisp and sour up front, but with a pastry-like body and softness behind it; it has more substance than some sour beers. Theres a definite, pleasant sweetness and heaviness to it. The cherries are subtle, but strong enough to be tasted. The finish turns dry and tannic, cleaning up some of the voluptuousness of the beer. Good.
At Rockwells. Very good balance between tweet and tart, cherrys both sour and sweet. Very nice. Serving: Tap

A strong cherry aroma. Brown color. This is really quite good. The cherry is evident throughout, but it isnt sweet like a maraschino or sticky either. Best fruit beer Ive had in a long long time. Small doses only of course, but excellent.
Pours a dark brown with light tan head. Taste is mostly sweet with a little tartness.
Deep orange-brown pour, small white head. Tart aroma of cherry, raspberry, plum. Flavor is quite sweet and tart, of cherry and apple.
Deep brown with a light khaki head. Nose is sweet cherry, lightly tart, and yeast. Cherry, sugar, light florals, hint of tartness, smooth finish m

Now that Duvel owns an international conglomerate of craft breweries, theyre starting to brew beers for multiple brands at multiple breweries. Boulevard has made Ommegang beers and now Liefmans has too. Though in this case Id say its not a bad thing at all. Ommegang Rosetta is quite similar to Liefmans Fruitese or Kriek, but not as overly sweet or sour as either of those beers, respectively. Big cherry flavor with plenty of authentic fruit flavor, sweetness and a nice tartness as well. This is a fun beer.

I pour an 11.2oz bottle into a tulip glass. It had a best before date of 10/2020 and cost $3.99 ($0.36 per ounce).

Appearance: Dark maroon/burgundy color with bright red highlights. Pours to a fairly large, off-white, soapy head which mostly dissipates but does leave some nice lacing.

Smell: Essentially cherry puree. Sweet and tart. Seems authentic, though.

Taste: Fruit beers are an interesting bunch: theyre sweet, tart and sometimes sour. One thing they dont tend to taste like is traditional beer and yet most beer purists are okay with that. Id include myself among that group, especially in the case of this beer. Theres plenty of authentic cherry flavor from beginning to end. Up front its like a sundae topping, through the middle theres just a touch of bitterness and it finishes with a short, sharp tart bite. The tartness lingers and theres perhaps a hint of sourness in there somewhere, but this is most definitely not a traditional lambic or any kind of lacto/brett wild ale. Of course, I could see barrel-aging it making it even better (if done correctly). The palette is pretty simplistic and repetitive, yet I enjoy it as much at the end as the beginning. Its a liquid dessert.

Drinkability: At 5.6% ABV, Ommegang Rosetta is actually quite efficient for its body. The mouthfeel is rather light and thin; not crisp like a lager but far from any kind of cloying, sticky sensation. In fact, Id criticize it for finishing too clean, in fact. Still, its a liquid dessert and quite tempting to throw back several of these in a row.

RATING: 9/10

Hint of cheese. Moderate sweet taste, but not as sweet as many belgian fruit beers can be, less sweet than expected, with a decent mild to moderate bitter taste, too. Just a mild bite on the finish. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Surprisingly tasty, slightly darker fruit beer.

Fresh cherry with a tinge of toilet bowl cleaner (no joke, theres something odd about it to my olfactories, but it passes as the beer breathes); auburn color, thin tan head; cherry, caramel maltiness, not overly sweet, very slight acidity, medium light body, ample carbonation; quite enjoyable and refreshing.

Dark hazy brown color with off-white head and thick lacing. Aroma and flavor have strong cherry notes. Slightly sugary, syrupy, and sticky. Super carbonated- bubbly sweetness tastes like a soda. Good overall

Poured from bottle into snifter. Pours brown with undertones of red. Head is thick and off-white. Aroma - rich smell of cherry fruit and cherry juice. Taste follows with rich cherry flavor, a little bit of earthiness, then finishes slightly sweet with a lingering taste of tart cherry juice. Reminds me of the cherries that grew in my grandparents back yard as a boy.
Dark red with solid head. Nose sour cherries, a bit of vinegar. Taste is cherry, a bit tart, wood, a bit dry on the finish. A lot of body for a kriek.

Pours brown with a light tan head. Aroma is dried cherry, a bit earthy, light wood. Taste is mildly tart cherry at first, light vinegar, then into a sweeter more dried cherry flavor. Decent balance, good brew.

Pours a deep dark ruby brown with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly......aroma of crushed cherries, damp earthy wood.....taste is sour, sour cherry, oaken hint, touch of vinegar, finishing a touch metallic.

11.2 oz. bottle purchased at Julios Liquors. Paid $3.99 before the Wild Six discount. Dark brown color, thin white head. Label reads best before 07 / 2020. A shelf life of more then four years at 5.6 %.... Really?? Ok Aroma is layered cherries, sweet malt, subtle wood notes. 
The flavor has a balanced malt and cherry skins and just a mild tart hint in finish. Sweet but never cloying. Its been years since I have had Liefmans Kriek but memories of that brew come to mind. Considering what you will pay for a Liefmans Kriek in the U.S this is a very nice option. Ok, perhaps this will hold a few years for cellar aging. It may produce some funky character that will go with the cherry. This is a pretty solid brew and much better then I would have guessed.

330 mL bottle from The Hop Yard, Raleigh, NC. Dark brown pour with a frothy tan head. Aroma of tart cherry and apple cider vinegar. The taste is a marriage of sour cherries, damp oak, lemon zest, and green apple. Slightly dry finish with lingering tartness. Hovers the line between fruit beer and sour but is a nice addition to the Ommegang line-up.
33cl bottle. Reddish brown pour off white head. Aroma is sweet cherry and light brown sugar. Flavor is sweetish cherry. Not a whole lot here surprised at the ratings.

Bottle. Dark ruby brown pour with a short tan head. Wonderful cherry aroma with soft sour notes, light wood and faint balsamic. Taste is sour cherries and sweet black cherries mixed with wood and light acetic notes. Body is light-medium with a strong, prickly carbonation. Slightly dry finish as well. Ends with more bold cherry notes, light wood and light balsamic. Very nice!

Pours dark brown with a large tan head. The aroma has lush cherries, abbey yeasty smoothness, some toast, vanilla and an oak quality - nice. It has a medium smooth body with lots of soft carbonation. The flavor starts with caramel, toasty malt, vanilla, cherries and a lushness to it all. The finish is clean and has smooth abbey yeast mixing with the rest. Solid.
A burnt sienna color pour with semi-creamy lasting head. Aroma of dark cherries and the flavor follows. Tastes like a Belgian brown ale with subtly tart cherries.

330 ml bottle. Very dark brown with just a little amber. A beige head that begins fizzy. Big cherries in the aroma along with some earth. Those are also tasted but the fruit is not nearly as big as in the nose. Softer malts are smooth and rich. The cherry is sweet but also a bit tart. Yeast and earth. This is interesting in that the cherries are just a little subdued. Everything here works well together. I liked it more than expected and ended up thinking this is the way a kriek should be done.

330 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, best before 7/2020. Pours fairly clear deep ruby red/brownish color with a 2 finger dense and rocky khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big tart cherry, berries, green apple, red grape, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, hay, straw, light pepper, light leather/funk, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of cherries, fruity/earthy yeast, and dark/bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of big tart cherry, berries, green apple, red grape, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, hay, straw, light pepper, light leather/funk, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate fruity tartness and yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of cherry, berries, green apple, red grape, caramel, brown sugar, toasted bread, hay, straw, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of cherries, fruity/earthy yeast, and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great sweet/tartness/spiciness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium-high carbonation and medium body; with a very smooth and lightly creamy/bready/acidic mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent fruited Belgian brown ale style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of cherries, fruity/earthy yeast, and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth and easy to drink with the balanced tartness/acidity. A very enjoyable offering.
Aroma is sour cherries, mild sweetness and a slight off hint. The flavor is sour cherries, malts and a mix of tart and mild sweetness in the finish.

Bottle from Julios. Pours out a dark reddish brown. Frothy tan head. Tart cherry aromas and flavor. Sweetness is nicely balanced with dark roasty malts. Could use more chocolate! Otherwise, very drinkable.

25 Nov 2015, bottle. brown. nose is cherries, slightly sweet, faintly tart, some alcohol. med body and moderately fizzy. this is very nice. bread/toast malt base layer with Liedmans cherry (cherry lifesavers) on top. Not too sweet though. might remind me of warm cherry crumble.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, hazy dark reddish brown pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of nice cherry, berry, lemon, oak, some acid into sweet fruits, some spice. Taste was a mix of cherry, grape, dark fruit into caramel, toffee, nice acidic notes, oak, finishing slightly sweet, slightly tart. Tasty.

Bottle in LA. Pours clear reddish deep brown, fine head. Mild acidic aroma, fine carbonation and cherry aroma and sweetness up front, dry finish with just a mild tartness. Fine prickly carbonation. Really well balanced, the cherry, sweetness and acidity are all in good harmony. Nice beer.

bravo. I bought this and was excited to crack it... immediately the flavor brought back memories of my first days exploring Belgian beer. After 15 minutes of smiling I had to check into ratebeer to see whats up... aw... Liefmans... so thats it. Okay. Love it. 4 packs for me in America. So so good.
Bottle. Pours brown, big head. Aroma of tart cherry, flavor is initially tart cherry, vinegar, then caramel malt. Delicious limbic that Ill be buying more of.
From a 12 oz bottle purchased at the brewery. Pours a clear mahogany with an ecru head. Aroma of plums or sweet cherries. Flavors of dark cherries and caramel. Slighlty sweet finish.

33 cl bottle, bb 07-2020. Brown with a lasting creamy foam. Nose is cherry, toffee and light vinegar. Flavors of mildly sour cherry, pear, brown sugar and a touches of wooden hop and cocoa. Light-medium body has medium-high but smooth carbonation and a nice balance.

Dark mahogeny pour with giant almond head. Smell is sweet and sour cherries and a noticeable malt body. Taste is mildly sweet dark cherries, lightl candy, medium light body. Just a hint of tart. Good.
Dark brown with red tones. Minimal lacing and head poured into mug. Coffee and nut scents. Nutty taste with tart cherry notes. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Not my favorite fruit beer.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- best by 7 / 2020. Nearly opaque dark brown color (no cherry red overtones), long-lasting 1/2" beige head, sheets of lace. Aroma of malt and some bing cherry. Taste is malt that is immediately joined by tart fresh cherry. Medium carbonation joins in on the swallow, with all parts moving to a lingering finish that becomes more and more tart, semi-sweet cherry. An outstanding sour fruit beer.

330ml bottle - $1.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Best Before: 07 2020.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown, ruby-tinted body with just at an inch of deflating, though sustained off-white foam.

Smell: Sweet-smelling, sugar-spiced cherries, moderately tart, with a dusting of baking spices.

Taste: Fairly sweet, though, thankfully, its not overly so, followed with a pop of tart, sweet cherry fruitiness. Subtle spicy quality with a little underlying woodsy, earthiness. Sweet-tart, fruity finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation.

Overall: I thought you all should know I found it better than Id anticipated, as it met my hopes of: not being too sweet (even if specifically sweetened) or syrupy, not being painfully artificial and being refreshingly carbonated.

Small bottle in a taster. Pours ruby/brown with an off-white head. Aroma of cherries, some light tartness, some malty sweetness, and hints of spice. Flavor the same with a nice cherry and tartness blend. Average texture. Maybe a little too sweet, but better than I was expecting.

Tallahassee, Fl - ABC Fine Wine & Spirits - Betton - 11.2 oz bottle. Dark ruby red pour, filmy mocha colored head with nice sticky lacing. Aroma has some nice cherry accents, a hint of sweet tarts candy. Succulent flavor with sour cherry accents, light vanilla accents, some roasted notes. Nice thick, rich mouthfeel.
Pours deep mahogany into a tulip. Off-white head quickly recedes to mottle surface. Cherry aromas. Thick with sweet and sour cherry and oak front to back. Lasting, dry tart finish.

This was poured into a stemmed pilsener glass. 
The appearance was a dark brown color with a one finger white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace. Lacing spider webs nicely.
The smell had a sweet to tart cherry over top of a nice maltiness. 
The taste was mainly sweet with a light tart cherry underneath. Light sweet to tart cherry leads into the aftertaste and slides into the finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Carbonation runs fairly light allowing the tartness make an effort to be the harshness but still just has an all around nicely balanced feel. 
Overall, I say this was a pretty good fruit beer for the cherry side of the house. Tartness is tame enough to win a good amount of fans for this one.

bottle. muddy brown, barely some red highlights under a beige head. nice big cherry ball candy aroma with mild tartness and sweetness. flavor is the same. really similar to a beer i just had (delirium red) with a bit more attenuation. i thought that was good, but this is spectacular!

Unexpectedly exceeded expectations. Just grabbed randomly since I lime ommegang in general but this was quite nice. Deep brown with tinge of purple and fine head. Nose is cherry and malt. Tastes of cherry, wine grapes, malt, yeast, wood. Everything works well together and not sweet. Nice deep flavors.

Deep plummy Amber/ brown with a rocky light tan head that doesnt take too long to dissipate. Lovely nose with slightly tart cherry, dark Belgian malt, a kiss of toast, funky Belgian esters and candu sugar. Smooth and fruity tart flavor with nice cherry flavors throughout, some Belgian candy sugar sweetness, and a bit of dark malt chewiness. Really nice and slightly tart and fruity and balanced and clean.

330 ml single bottle from Tipsys. Deep, dark ruby red and clear appearance with a nice-sized, light tan head. Aroma of sweet and tart cherries with hints of toffee, vanilla, nuts and caramel malt. Similar flavor, fruity, moderately sweet and lightly tart. Light to medium body with ample carbonation, a smooth creamy feel and a lingering, light earthy bitter finish. A little too sweet for me, but a pretty solid fruit beer overall.
bottle. deep maroon with small head. agree with others who describe this as a kriek. light tartness with big fruity cherry flavor. mild carbonation, and a lingering very mild sweetness.

Dark clear autumn color, thick head, spotty lacing. Tart, then sweet, cherries throughout. The small carbonation adds character to the mouthfeel in the middle accentuating the tart, then ends sweet. Quite good.

330 ml. bottle poured to my sampler glass at the 2015 Lakeshore Beverage Trade Show in Chicago, showing a deep burgundy color, with a modest layer of off white head foam that quickly reduced to a persistent ring, and left clingy strands of lacing on the glass. The nose was expressive cherry, dark grape, with sweetness, and some vinous nature. Medium bodied, and nicely effervescent, the taste continued the esters, showed some lightly sticky texture, but was tart and thoroughly refreshing.

Pours a cola color with a slim off-white head. Aroma is very nice with lots of cherry, licorice and some sweet notes with a hint of funk. Flavor is medium sweet leading into a quenching tart finish and good carbonation. Good brew.
Pours a medium brown with small head. Aromas of light cherry and a touch of wood. Flavors of slightly tart cherry with hints of wood.

Nice sour beer. Very similar to a Kriek. The cherry aroma is really nice, not artificial or too sweet. Same in the taste. Killed the bottle quick. Brewed in Belgium for Ommegang. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2015 This beer was brewed at Liefmans in Belgium. It tastes almost exactly like the old Liefmans Kriek, which hasnt been produced in years. Cherry flavor is perfect; not cloying, artificial, or syrupy. Excellent balance of acidity and mouthfeel. Almost impossible to drink slowly. Awesome sour beer, and my new favorite cherry beer. And at $9.99 / 4pk, I consider this a great deal. The original Liefmans Kriek was $7 for a 375ml.
Fine cherry flavor with firm malt background. 11.2 ounce bottle for $3.69 was a bit pricey.
